title: 109_hr1240
content: The Act may be cited as the "Emergency Medical Services Support Act". Federal Interagency Committee on Emergency Medical Services is established. The "Emergency Medical Services Support Act" establishes the Federal Interagency Committee on Emergency Medical Services (Interagency Committee on EMS) to improve coordination and support for emergency medical services. Membership includes officials from various departments such as the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration and the Health Resources and Services Administration. The Emergency Medical Services Support Act establishes the Federal Interagency Committee on Emergency Medical Services, which includes officials from various departments such as the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, United States Fire Administration, Centers for Medicare Medicaid Services, Department of Defense, Indian Health Service, Federal Communications Commission, and other Federal agencies. The Interagency Committee on EMS, established under the Emergency Medical Services Support Act, includes representatives from various Federal agencies. The Committee selects a chairperson annually and ensures coordination among Federal agencies and State, local, tribal, and regional emergency medical services and 9-1-1 systems. The Interagency Committee on EMS, established under the Emergency Medical Services Support Act, includes representatives from various Federal agencies. It focuses on identifying and addressing the needs of State, local, tribal, and regional emergency medical services and 9-1-1 systems, integrating them with homeland security and other emergency response programs, recommending new programs for improvement, and streamlining Federal support processes. The Interagency Committee on EMS, established under the Emergency Medical Services Support Act, assists State, local, tribal, and regional emergency medical services in setting priorities, advising on implementation of coordinated State EMS programs, and meeting regularly to discuss matters related to EMS. The Administrator of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration provides administrative support to the Committee. The Interagency Committee on EMS prepares and submits an annual report to Congress on its activities, actions, and recommendations, including details on Federal agency responsibility and support for emergency medical services systems. The Federal Interagency Committee on Emergency Medical Services Advisory Council is established. The Federal Interagency Committee on Emergency Medical Services Advisory Council (Advisory Council) consists of up to 13 individuals with expertise in emergency medical services. Members are selected to represent urban and rural areas, as well as all sectors of the EMS community. The Council annually chooses a chairperson and makes recommendations to the Interagency Committee on EMS on various topics. The Interagency Committee on EMS focuses on improving coordination and support of emergency medical services systems among Federal programs, developing a national EMS plan, setting standards and guidelines, creating grants for community-based EMS improvement, and enhancing workforce development and training. The Advisory Council reviews and provides independent information or recommendations for the annual report of the Interagency Committee on EMS. They meet concurrently with the Committee and may hold separate meetings for public input. Compensation for Advisory Council members is also addressed. The Advisory Council members do not receive pay for their service but are allowed travel expenses. The Administrator of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, with support from the Department of Homeland Security, provides administration support to the Council.
